qas.question: What do some authors state anthropology developed as the study of?
A past society would be an other culture separated by what temporal aspect?
What other cultures are said to be separated by space, what is actually meant?
Who published a book with unnecessarily long title, "Exploring the City: Inquires Toward an Urban Anthropology"?
When did anthropologists stop looking for cultures far away and instead began to "look across the tracks"?
What do some authors argue developed as the study of western culture in terms of time and space?
When did anthropologist specializing in other culture start searching in the "Third World"?

context: Some authors argue that <b5_0>anthropology<b5_0/> originated and developed as the study of <a0_0>"other cultures<a0_0/>", both in terms of <a1_0>time<a1_0/> (past societies) and space (<a2_0>non-European/non-Western societies<a2_0/>). For example, the classic of urban anthropology, <a3_0>Ulf Hannerz<a3_0/> in the introduction to his seminal Exploring the City: Inquiries Toward an Urban Anthropology mentions that the "Third World" had habitually received most of attention; anthropologists who traditionally specialized in "other cultures" looked for them far away and started to look "across the tracks" <a4_0>only in late <b6_0>1960s<a4_0/>.
